There's an old Nordic saying: Iceland is green and Greenland is icy. And it's true; holiday photos from Iceland have an unreal quality, like a still from Lord of the Rings doctored by a Photoshop expert to play around with, whilst 80% of Greenland's surface closely resembles the ice planet Hoth from the second Star Wars film. It's not really that green in Greenland, but it is in Iceland.

However, the average European has quite a different perception of the sub-Arctic climate which, combined with the blanket coverage of Iceland's dire financial situation, puts it just above Resolution Island in the league table of consideration when booking a mini-break. But they'd be very wrong.

One of the bizarre side-products of the titanic currency fluctuations of late is that Reykjavik is now amazingly cheap to holiday makers, in direct opposition to its long-standing image as a painfully expensive place to have fun. I was there during the summer and a beer at Kaffibarrin, the popular city centre drinking den that's famously part-owned by Damon Albarn, cost between £6 and £7 (when translated into pounds). The same beer now costs about £2.50 due to the free-falling currency, cheaper than virtually any barrel scrapings you could find in the very seediest London pub.

And a fine piece of Icelandic lamb, the most delicious you'll ever taste and expertly cooked using local ingredients in the sort of well-to-do restaurant usually found in Knightsbridge, costs the equivalent of £10. That wouldn't even buy you a burger in most English pubs, let alone a cut of the finest meat the region has to offer. Also now cheaper than takeaway fish and chips is lamb's tongue - a delicacy of the highest order. The texture is, well, that of tongue but it's indescribably meaty and full of herby flavour.

Iceland is still exactly the same, enchanting place. When you turn a street corner in Reykjavik, a city about the same size as Cambridge, and see the 3000-foot Esja mountain range through the red roof tops, the sight demands that you stop and gawp for at least a few seconds, even if you've seen it a dozen times before that morning. It is one of the most stunning backdrops to a capital city anywhere in the world with its snow-capped outcrops, often draped with fog and the odd hardy sheep, towering over the ice-cold bay.

Thankfully the people have also changed very little despite impending financial hardship troubling many citizens – something many blame their European neighbours for not helping stave off. Brown and Darling are still two very dirty words in Iceland but most are intelligent enough to realise that their actions do not reflect the will of the public in general, despite publicity to the contrary. "Most people I know think of it as a problem between governments, but I am not sure everyone thinks the way me and my friends do. I think people are just grateful for the foreign currency tourists bring," is how one Icelandic journalist put it to me and, having spent a week there recently, I would have to agree.

Apart from the odd beer-fuelled comment about what an ass our government is (few Brits would or could disagree), people put on a brave face and welcome tourists with open arms, just as they have since Reykjavik became a magnet for your tourists in the 1990s.

The city's tourist board recorded a 20% increase in British tourists travelling to Iceland in September and the first half of October, compared to the same period last year. Some will have been journalists and media types scrabbling to cover the crisis but most are just canny holidaymakers taking advantage of the unique fiscal climate to have an extremely memorable holiday on a credit crunch budget.

So if the sort of scenery that makes people sit on a plane for days to get to New Zealand would be of interest then Iceland, a mere 180 minutes from London, should be your next destination. The food and drink are so cheap you might think you've ended up in Eastern Europe, but that wouldn't be quite as exquisite.

Few people have been more persona non grata than George Bush during this election season. Republican candidates have gone out of their way to avoid being seen with the president. In fact, Bush has raised $40m less for the Republican party and its candidates in the 2008 election than he did last cycle. However, John McCain is becoming equally as toxic. He is, in fact, becoming the next George Bush.

In recent months, McCain has made a particular effort to separate himself from the president and shrug off the liberal talking point that his policies would represent Bush's third term. In September, McCain campaign chief Rick Davis gave Bloomberg News an "emphatic no" when asked whether the two men would be campaigning together this fall, saying that they had "turned that page". (This attitude is a far cry from what McCain said about Bush last February: "I'd be honoured to be anywhere with him under any circumstances.")

Nevertheless, even solid Republicans are now equating McCain with Bush. Norm Coleman, facing a tough Senate re-election race in Minnesota, never mentioned McCain at multiple campaign stops. Last month, an aide to Coleman refused to back McCain's healthcare plan, curiously saying only that Coleman was "aligned with senator Coleman's plan". He also called for the McCain campaign to stop its negative robocalls.

At least two other Republicans, Gordon Smith of Oregon and Susan Collins of Maine, also broke rank and joined the anti-robocall chorus. Smith has gone even further, grabbing hold of Barack Obama's coattails and going out of his way to praise the Democratic candidate.

Republican senatorial committee chairman John Ensign of Nevada recently told MSNBC that there was "no question the top of the ticket is affecting our Senate races, and it's making it a lot more difficult." Senate minority leader Mitch McConnell, in a tight re-election race in Kentucky, hasn't done any events with McCain since a fundraiser last spring.

Few Republicans have come out excited by the direction McCain is taking the party. In fact, the Republican National Committee's website currently has no mentions of McCain on its front page. Obama's name, however, appears five times. The top landing graphic links to a speech by former senator Fred Thompson. (The graphic does eventually change to a McCain promotion, but you have to wait around more than 10 seconds.)

Many conservatives already view their presidential candidate as a lame duck. According to Politico's Jonathan Martin, a "who's who of conservative leaders" is planning a major strategy session for November 6 to chart out the movement's future. Republicans are publicly criticising McCain and his campaign with increasing frequency. While some have decried his Karl Rove-like tactics, those voices have mostly come from the old guard, such as representative Chris Shays of Connecticut and Colin Powell. More are urging McCain to be more aggressive in fighting for conservative causes.

The one person on the McCain campaign who has generated excitement is Sarah Palin, who seems to already be gearing up for a 2012 run. She has been more than willing to hit Obama for "palling around with terrorists" and attack his "socialist" policy proposals. In her energy policy speech this week, Palin repeatedly veered away from her prepared remarks by substituting "our administration" for every reference to the "McCain administration".

Former House speaker and conservative revolution leader Newt Gingrich retired from Congress in 1999, but he certainly hasn't gone away quietly. In fact, he's shaping up to be a mover in the next conservative shake-up. A constant presence on Fox News, Gingrich has been a thorn in McCain's side. Gingrich has also been moulding the next generation of Republican foot soldiers in Congress, allegedly whipping up last-minute opposition to the financial bail-out package last month. (Gingrich has denied this involvement.) Additionally, Gingrich has invested considerable resources into an energy campaign urging: "Drill Here. Drill Now. Pay Less." He even appeared as a "guest star" in the GOP energy protest over the summer, which conservatives considered "America's greatest hour".

Congressmen such as Jeb Hensarling of Texas, Mike Pence of Indiana and Thaddeus McCotter of Michigan are typical of Gingrich's foot soldiers. They are intent on moving away from Bush, who decimated the Republican party, and McCain, who isn't ideological enough on issues such as immigration. The New Republic's Eve Fairbanks described this new guard as "fiercely stubborn, gutsily insubordinate, drama-loving and … unadulteratedly ideological."

A new direction doesn't necessarily mean success. Just as both Gingrich's Contract with America and Tom DeLay's infamous 1994 Republican revolution eventually failed, this new conservative direction may also find itself unable to live up to its own standards. One thing seems certain, however: Neither McCain nor Bush will be leading the way.

The dislocated head of a baby doll stares blindly through the gate; WALL-E and Barbie Pet Doctor boxes are strewn across the yard.

Two weeks ago, toymaking giant Smart Union was churning out goods for children across the United States and Europe. Now it is in liquidation and 7,000 former employees are in shock.

"One day we went to work as usual, the next it was all closed," said Wei Sunying, gazing through the barred gate of the factory in Dongguan in southern China where she spent eight years painting plastic components in a fume-filled room.

"Thousands of us are looking for jobs now. We walk around every day till our feet ache but we can't find anything."

Few in the west have heard of Dongguan, but the chances are that your shoes, your TV or your children's toys originated here. Exports have built a city of up to 14 million inhabitants — twice the population of Greater London — almost all migrant workers from the countryside. Its economy has grown 15% annually in recent years.

Now the global financial and economic crisis is proving the final straw for exporters already punished by rising costs and a stronger currency.

In the last year, chill winds have blown through the baking Pearl River Delta. Sixty-seven thousand small and medium-sized businesses in China collapsed in the first half of 2008, many in these manufacturing heartlands, says the national economic planning body. Toy firms have been particularly badly hit, thanks to safety scares and product recalls. Textile firms, with wafer-thin margins, are also reeling.

Next came tighter credit for many foreign-owned firms, such as Hong Kong's Smart Union. And then, in the last two months, a sharp drop in US and European demand as consumers reined in spending.

A local trade association predicts that by the end of January, Dongguan and its neighbours Shenzhen and Guangzhou will lose 9,000 of their 45,000 factories.

"Many factories are looking at completely empty order books," warned Stephen Green, head of China research at Standard Chartered, who believes the export sector will be stagnant and could even shrink next year.

Green predicts that China will grow 7.9% next year — well below the double-digit figures enjoyed over the last half decade — while others suggest it could fall closer to 7%.

That sounds enviable to western countries facing recession. But with the working age population still growing, China needs at least 8% growth to maintain the current employment rate. And the fall-out will be highly concentrated in provinces such as Guangdong.

"The social impact of this is going to be huge. The problems are getting bigger and bigger," said Wooyeal Paik, who is researching Dongguan's industry and migrant workforce at the University of California at Los Angeles.

"Impromptu protests by disgruntled workers left jobless and without pay are becoming more common; they have resorted to petitioning local officials for backpay because they have few other ways to remonstrate and be compensated.

"They will complain more and they will go to local government offices more... You will see demonstrations and picketing. And probably there's a risk of violence against bosses — especially foreigners."

Dongguan's government stepped in to reimburse the Smart Union workers to the tune of 24,000 yuan (£2.2m) after thousands gathered at the factory gates and outside local authority offices.

But two months' back pay — 1200 yuan for most — will not last long. There is no redundancy package and a lawsuit by workers appears to have limited prospects of success.

Wei, from Guizhou, is one of many struggling to find new work. Even if she could read the job adverts, most ask for recruits under 35; she is just over 40.

"I came here as a migrant worker because my children need money for schooling," she said.

"Now I can't support my children. I don't even have enough money to get back home and it's expensive to stay here."

Even job offers aren't always what they seem, said 26-year-old Fang Jianlin, whose friends were recently conned.

"Recruiters told them the conditions and the salaries were very good, but on the way to the place they were asked for money. They got robbed; some were even beaten," he said.

Smart Union was such a popular employer that Fang paid a hefty "introduction fee" to win his job there. At worst, he and his wife would earn around 600 yuan a month; at the busiest times, when production ran until 2am, they could take home 2,100 yuan each.

But he and his wife will return to his village in Sichuan in a few days, where his parents are rearing their children, unless new work turns up. They are not sure how they will support the family, but cannot afford the 50 yuan a day in rent, food and transport to stay here.

It's a sobering end to the dream which lures millions of workers to Dongguan each year, where they struggle and study their way towards the promise of a regular income; perhaps even a place in the burgeoning middle classes. At the city's night schools, thousands of workers end their long days with classes on everything from car maintenance to law.

Bob Li is one of the area's success stories. He arrived in 1995 as a casual labourer. "Everyone in my hometown had heard Guangdong was covered in gold," he said.

Now he manages a factory for Richall, which supplies durable bags to companies such as Walmart, Carlsberg and Disney. Twenty-five thousand totes for Tesco are stacked up awaiting delivery.

But he is unnerved by the economic downturn.

"These days it is getting more and more difficult for factories like us," he said, citing the cost of wages and materials.

"The exchange rate is already a huge issue here; people are losing interest. The price of our materials has risen because they're made from oil... Taken together, costs have risen by 30%-40%."

To some extent, Dongguan has become a victim of its own success. The rising prosperity of the region has created inflationary pressures. Workers want higher wages; new labour laws are designed to wipe out sweatshops but bring higher costs, which squeeze many companies.

Manufacturers have already fled inland to cheaper provinces, in many cases encouraged by Guangdong authorities, who hoped to move the province up the value chain — condensing 200 years of western industrial history into fewer than 15.

"We have a policy to empty the cage for the new birds," Guangdong's vice-governor, Wan Qingliang, told reporters this month.

"The ultimate target is to build the Pearl River Delta into the core region of modern manufacturing."

Others are unsure of the wisdom of the policy in the face of a worldwide downturn.

"Places like Guangdong miscalculated the development of the economy. They actually tried to push those labour intensive and small and medium sized enterprises out of the [established industrial] area because they wanted hi-tech industries there. But when something bad happens, like the economic downturn, what are they going to do?" said Paik.

He acknowledges that numerous East Asian economies, such as Japan, have moved up the value chain in just the same way; and that the Chinese government deserves to be confident, given its economic record.

"But they haven't experienced a serious economic downturn except right after 1989 and have been overconfident in their policy of the quick transformation of industrial structure toward hi-tech in Guangdong," he cautioned.

The risk is that officials push the city off the economic ladder rather than up it. Whether new subsidies, export tax rebates and other support for small businesses can save them remains to be seen.

Yet China's rising living standards in the 30 years since economic reforms were launched has left most people optimistic about its long-term prospects. Migrant workers returning home think they may come back in a few years. A security guard at the shuttered Smart Union plant is plotting out his course to university.

"If we compare the situation to when I first arrived, I have already found my pot of gold," said Li, the factory manager.

"But I can still see it's just the beginning."

They are both highly significant political figures in their home state of California, and devote all of their free time to campaigning. The difference however, is that whilst Rima is a Democrat, her brother is a staunch Republican.

"It's just our make-up and the paths we've taken," said Tareef. "I started out a small businessman, she was always an activist with causes, so the Democrats were the best fit for her. The older I got, the more conservative I became. I think having children changes you."

When you ask Rima why her views are so different to her brother's she takes a deep breath. "Seriously", she says in a sombre tone, "He was dropped on his head as a baby."

In next month's presidential election, the majority of America's 2.4 million Muslims are likely to vote with Rima rather than Tareef.

A survey carried out by the Pew Research Centre last year found that 63% of American Muslims identify with the Democrats as compared with 11% for Republicans.

The votes of Arab Muslims however, are less difficult to predict.

This group, which makes up one quarter of America's total Muslim population, tends to be more conservative than their black and Asian counterparts. In Rima and Tareef's home of Orange county, the Arab Muslim population has helped sustain Republican rule.

"Arabs are often socially conservative and successful in business, so they tend to assume they are Republican," said Rima. "But they never look up the fine print of what that means."

Tareef might not look like a traditional Republican, but his values are totally in tune with the party. As a highly paid manager in a construction firm, Tareef says he finds the small government, low tax and anti-union policies of the right attractive because they suit his business. He also says he is "automatically drawn in" by the social values of the party - family, order, patriotism - on account of his ethnicity.

Rima also has a high-flying career. In between her duties as the vice chair of the Democratic Party for Orange County, she holds down a day job at American International Group (AIG).

So why is Rima - given that she is an Arab-Muslim property owner who helps manage an investment bank - not also voting for the right? "If I were to follow the herd I'd be a Republican, but you have to be socially responsible," she said. "In truth it's got nothing to do with my background - the Democrats are simply a party for people who believe in good jobs, good education and a balanced budget."

Although both Rima and Tareef admit that their political beliefs are often a source of conflict, they insist that politics has never got in the way of their close personal relationship. Rima – who doesn't have children of her own - moved from Seal Beach to Laguna Hills to be closer to her brother and his family.

She can regularly be found at Tareef's house indulging in some of his Arabic cooking, "I know where my bread is buttered, know what I'm saying?" she says with a chuckle, "Of course we have heated arguments over dinner - I rub his nose in the last hardcore Republican that's converted to the Democrats - but it's friendly competition and sibling rivalry at its best. We never let politics get in the way. Family comes first."

In fact at times, the ideological split between Rima and Tareef doesn't so much feel like a hostile dividing line, but an affectionate bond that brings them closer together – they are like two peas in a politically confused pod.

Perhaps their most amusing collaborative endeavour is their joint stand-up comedy routine You the Republican, Me the Democrat, which raised $120,000 for the Middle East Student Initiative earlier this year. In these entirely improvised shows, Tareef stands at the podium whilst Rima wonders about the audience heckling him from a cordless mike.

"It just comes out spontaneously," said Rima. "He'll say something like 'You might be a Democrat Sis but we're still in Orange county!' and I'll say 'Yeah right – but have you looked at the electoral register recently?'"

Rima's jibe hits home. In Orange county and elsewhere, the Republican's traditional base of Arab-Muslim support has been slowly slipping away under the policies pursued by President Bush since 9/11.

According to Pew's research, 71% of Muslims who describe themselves as conservative say they now disapprove of Bush's performance. The terrorism-driven clamp down on civil liberties at home and the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan abroad have tested the loyalty of some of the party's most devout Arab supporters.

"The fine print of what it means to be a Republican is coming to the surface and the community is starting to change," said Rima. "Obama's victory shows that people are sick of the status quo – we can win this election."

For once Tareef agrees with his sister, admitting that it has become harder to hold his head up as a Republican in the Muslim community. "People ask me how I can still be a member and I say I chose the party because of its ideals, not because of its presidency," he said.

"In the past the Republican party was the leader of ethnic outreach. But then the neo-cons came and the Republicans have fallen behind. Of course it can be changed if the right people come along, but I don't think McCain will make any difference. He has deep-seated issues with the Arab world."

Rima notes with a smile, "My brother is more of a Democrat than he thinks."

Since 9/11 Rima and Tareef have found their political beliefs steadily moving closer together. It started in 2002 when the Bush administration brought in "special registration". Introduced in reaction to the terrorist attacks, this legislation required every Arab male over 16 to register with the government. Failing to register or produce legal documentation was grounds for deportation. No other migrant communities were subject to these procedures.

"It was a flashback to the regressive regimes many people left to pursue the American dream," said Rima. "Stereotyping, discrimination – it was the worst kind of racial profiling."

Both siblings opposed the proposals, "Rima would lobby the Democrats and I would lobby the Republicans," said Tareef. "When we speak on record together, people know we are speaking on behalf of the whole community because both parties are represented."

The siblings continued to work in coalition when the Iraq war started in 2003, sharing political contacts and organising joint community meetings.

"Most Republicans were so gung-ho about supporting the war I felt like a traitor for opposing it," said Tareef, "but the whole public basis for the war was lies and misconceptions."

"I've lived in the Middle East so I saw things through a different filter. I knew that Iraq and Afghanistan would never let a foreign power control them, and everything we warned about came true."

It was shortly after the Iraq war started that Tareef significantly scaled down his role in the Republican party, ending his presidency of the Arab American Club for Orange County in 2004 and stepping down from the state's central committee in 2006.

Although he cites health reasons and other priorities, he admits that Iraq, "along with the whole neo-con agenda" played some part in his decision to reduce his Republican commitments. Yet he refuses to hand in his membership. "If I leave then no one will listen to me," he said, "If you join a party and you disagree with a particular policy you have a democratic way of changing that. You have to be part of the system if you want it to change."

Children of a Palestinian family, Rima and Tareef were born and raised in Jerusalem. The Nashashibis have always been a political clan; their father was a co-founder of the Palestinian National Liberation League, and met the brother of his future wife whilst defending the city of Jerusalem in 1948.

"My father always encouraged my political activism as much as he did my brothers," said Rima, "Politics is in our blood as Palestinians and as Nashashibis."

The family moved to Orange county in 1980, but Rima regularly returns to her homeland, and in 2005 was sent by the state department to help run campaigning workshops for Palestinian women in the run up to the national elections. "I felt kinship with the people I was working with" she said, "We are one people, whether we are in the diaspora or the occupied territories. A lot of them want me to move back, but I know that staying in the States is the best way to help them. The real decisions are made here."

Although Rima is convinced that Obama would offer more hope for Palestinians than McCain, she is not unrealistic about the Democrats' potential for achieving peace in the Middle East, "If we're working on the same principles of Oslo and Madrid then anything we produce is going to be a band aid and not address the real cause of the problem," she said.

"I love the party but I don't love it blindly. The obligation is on us to educate party decisions."

Tareef, who also remains highly conscious of his roots, is equally sceptical of both parties' commitments to help his homeland.

"Foreign policy on this issue doesn't really change regardless of whether the government is Republican or Democrat. It depends who you are talking to – there are different personal, not party, platforms."

Irrespective of their political differences, Rima and Tareef both want change. At the moment, only Obama seems to be offering it.

The country will have to wait and see whether the Democrats' platform is enough to attract the disaffected Arab vote from its traditional Republican base.

Tareef's two children, Mufeed and Rasha, diplomatically keep their emerging political opinions to themselves. Whether they'll grow up to support Daddy's Republicans or Aunty's Democrats is not yet known.

A Colombian man, believed to be a major narcotics trafficker who threatened the lives of federal law enforcement officials, was secretly flown into the United States on a Customs Service plane and whisked yesterday morning to the federal court in Central Islip, New York, for arraignment.

Carlos Patino Restrepo, 44, was brought to the courthouse in an armored car that was part of a 10-vehicle convoy of federal agents and State Police cars. Patino Restrepo is charged with having brought tonnes of cocaine into the United States beginning in the 1990s, according to court documents.

The convoy with Patino Restrepo drove rapidly up to the courthouse yesterday morning. Some of the cars blocked off both ends of the roadway while the armored car carrying him went down a guarded ramp to the prisoner's entrance, according to one person who witnessed the scene.

Patino Restrepo was under arrest in Colombia by authorities there on suspicion of acting as a desaparecido - a presumed murderer who makes his rivals and possible informants disappear, according to newspaper accounts in Colombia.

In the United States, Patino Restrepo is being handled with unusually tight security because he has threatened to murder the federal prosecutor and the Immigration and Customs Enforcement agent who had been investigating his case for over a year, according to sources familiar with the situation.

The threats included detailed information on where they lived and their children, according to the sources. As a result, the prosecutor and the agent have been replaced and placed under guard by the US Marshals Service, and new prosecutors and agents have been assigned to the case, according to the sources.

Robert Nardoza, a spokesman for the US attorney's office, declined to comment on whether any threats against prosecutors or agents in the case were under investigation.

Patino Restrepo pleaded not guilty before a US district court judge, Joanna Seybert, who held him without bail as both a flight risk and a danger to the community.

Patino Restrepo's attorney, Todd Merer, of Manhattan, said the claims that his client wanted to kill the previous prosecutor and agent on the case were false, and based on the fraudulent testimony of two or three people in Colombia.

Merer said he could prove that the people who supposedly heard Restrepo make the threats were not even with him at the time.

Merer said he was unaware of the charges against his client in Colombia.

Bulls' blood gazpacho

This uncooked soup is a beautiful red colour, and is packed full of enough vitamins to ward off any evil spirits.
1 red cabbage
2 red onions
1 red pepper
2 sticks of celery
1/2 cucumber
1 medium red chilli
150ml red wine vinegar
2 slices stale bread, broken into breadcrumbs
Salt, pepper & olive oil to dress

Chop and seed all the vegetables finely and leave to macerate in the red wine vinegar in the fridge for two hours. Add the breadcrumbs and blend until smooth. Pass through a sieve, season to taste, and serve in small bowls or glasses with a drizzle of olive oil.

Chef's tip: For an adult version, add a splash of either Hendricks gin or quality vodka along with a teaspoon of seeded mustard.

Witches' hats

A dark chocolate dessert, three ways.
For the chocolate sauce
350ml water
300g caster sugar
150g quality cocoa powder
125g bitter chocolate (70%, preferably organic and Fairtrade)
400ml double cream

Place the water, cocoa powder and sugar into a pan and heat until dissolved. Break the chocolate into small pieces in a bowl and pour the hot mixture over to melt the chocolate. Add the double cream, mixing well. Set aside to cool to room temperature.

For the chocolate cones

125g bitter chocolate (as before)
Greaseproof paper

Draw a circle around a large dinner plate onto the greaseproof paper and cut out. Fold the paper in half to create a half moon and cut into two. Roll up each half to create a cone shape, and secure with a staple. Repeat until you have six cones.

Melt the chocolate in a glass bowl over simmering water, stirring and ensuring the water doesn't touch the bottom of the bowl.

Once melted, pour the chocolate into the cones, twisting to ensure even coverage. Place on to another sheet of greaseproof paper and put in the freezer. After about 2-3 minutes of cooling, remove with a palate knife on to another sheet, leaving a clean open base to the cone (eat the remaining chocolate button!). Place back in the freezer until ready to serve.

For the chocolate mousse

This mixture makes extra chocolate mousse that can be refrigerated and enjoyed later.

250ml dark chocolate, melted as before
800g double cream, whipped
1 whole egg
2 egg yolks
1 leaf gelatine
2 shots of Tuaca or Cointreau (optional)

Dissolve the gelatine, following the instructions on the pack.

Bring a pan of water to a gentle simmer. Place the egg and yolks into a large, clean bowl and place over the water. Using a balloon whisk or small hand-held electric whisk, whisk slowly and steadily until the mixture starts to turn a pale cream colour.

Add the dissolved leaf of gelatine to the mixture as you whisk. Increase your speed and continue whisking until a pale, stable foam forms. You should be able to lift up a ribbon of foam with the beaters that you could almost write with.

Remove from the heat and fold in the melted chocolate and whipped double cream (and the alcohol, if using). Try to keep as much air as possible in the mixture for a light result. Make sure the melted chocolate is not too hot, to avoid cooking the mixture.

To serve

Spoon the chocolate sauce into the centre of the plates to form the brim of the hat. Remove the chocolate cones from the freezer and using a piping bag fill each with chocolate mousse. Remove the greaseproof paper before placing in the centre of the chocolate sauce. Dust with a little icing sugar.

Chef's tip: Add some pink peppercorns to the plate to give a little heat, or garnish with homemade chocolate tuilles to create witches' brooms.

Bobbing for apples

An Autumnal cocktail inspired by our favourite Halloween game.

500ml freshly pressed organic apple juice (we use Chegworth valley)
6 shots of Tuaca [an Italian liqueur, optional]
2-3 medium-sized eating apples (Cox's are superb at this time of year)
Stem ginger syrup, to taste
3 vanilla pods
Caster sugar & cinnamon powder
Ice cubes

To prepare the vanilla pod straws: top and tail the vanilla pods and push a wooden skewer them to remove the seeds and create an opening. Chop each pod in half to create 2 straws, and leave to dry out for later.

Mix the apple juice and Tuaca, adding the stem ginger syrup to taste. Peel the apples and use melon baller to create marble-sized balls of apples. Add to the apple juice mixture immediately to prevent browning. If you haven't got a melon baller, chop the apple into small cubes. Pour the cocktail over ice, then strain into martini glasses rimmed with a mixture of the cinnamon and sugar. Serve with a vanilla straw.

Chef's tips: Make a mulled wine mixture (red wine, cinnamon and sugar) and simmer the apple balls in it for 5-7 minutes until cooked and a blood-red colour. Leave to cool in the mixture until ready to use.

Alternatively, dip the apple balls into caramel, leave to harden, then serve in the drink on a cocktail stick.
